articles.headline: Sharing, With a Safety Net
articles.snippet: A privacy bill for young people passed by California’s Legislature has put the state in the middle of a debate over how to protect those who share without thinking.
articles.abstract: A privacy bill for young people passed by California’s Legislature has put the state in the middle of a debate over how to protect those who share without thinking.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Kids. The reckless rants and pictures they post online can often get them in trouble, by compromising their chances of getting into a good college or even landing them in jail. What to do about such lapses vexes parents, school officials, the Internet companies that host their words and images — and the law.

articles.headline: Money Funds Are Circling the Wagons on Rules
articles.snippet: As proposed rules are weighed, the industry is fighting vigorously to avoid even weak regulation.
articles.abstract: As proposed rules are weighed, the industry is fighting vigorously to avoid even weak regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank regulators around the world are forcing banks to hold more capital than they did before the financial crisis revealed just how inadequate their capital truly was. But one set of American banks appears to be on the verge of keeping the right to have no capital at all.

articles.headline: U.S. Textile Plants Return, With Floors Largely Empty of People
articles.snippet: Textile factories are bustling again in the United States, but the savior was automation, meaning few of the jobs lost since the ’90s came back with the plants.
articles.abstract: Textile factories are bustling again in the United States, but the savior was automation, meaning few of the jobs lost since the ’90s came back with the plants.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAFFNEY, S.C. — The old textile mills here are mostly gone now. Gaffney Manufacturing, National Textiles, Cherokee — clangorous, dusty, productive engines of the Carolinas fabric trade — fell one by one to the forces of globalization.

articles.headline: Signs of Distress Multiplied on Killer’s Path to Navy Yard
articles.snippet: A call to a hotel where the Navy Yard gunman was staying before the shooting suggests that his employer had deep concerns about his state of mind and raises questions about his clearance to work at bases.
articles.abstract: A call to a hotel where the Navy Yard gunman was staying before the shooting suggests that his employer had deep concerns about his state of mind and raises questions about his clearance to work at bases.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the days before Aaron Alexis called the police in Newport, R.I., to complain that he was hearing voices sent by a “microwave machine,” employees at the Residence Inn in nearby Middletown were struggling to cope with his behavior.
articles.byline: By Erica Goode, Sarah Maslin Nir and Manny Fernandez

articles.headline: Iran Said to Seek a Nuclear Accord to End Sanctions
articles.snippet: Seizing on a perceived flexibility in a letter from President Obama to President Hassan Rouhani, Iran’s leaders are focused on getting quick relief from crippling sanctions, a top adviser to the Iranian leadership said.
articles.abstract: Seizing on a perceived flexibility in a letter from President Obama to President Hassan Rouhani, Iran’s leaders are focused on getting quick relief from crippling sanctions, a top adviser to the Iranian leadership said.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s leaders, seizing on perceived flexibility in a private letter from President Obama, have decided to gamble on forging a swift agreement over their nuclear program with the goal of ending crippling sanctions, a prominent adviser to the Iranian leadership said Thursday.
articles.byline: By Thomas Erdbrink and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Hurdles Are Still High for a New Fed Front-Runner
articles.snippet: The White House is worried that Janet L. Yellen could be a target for criticism before a formal nomination, and if she does lead the Federal Reserve, she must manage a stimulus easing in a weak job market.
articles.abstract: The White House is worried that Janet L. Yellen could be a target for criticism before a formal nomination, and if she does lead the Federal Reserve, she must manage a stimulus easing in a weak job market.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the favorite to succeed Ben S. Bernanke to lead the Federal Reserve, Janet L. Yellen faces no shortage of hurdles.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Annie Lowrey

articles.headline: Quick Turn of Fortunes as Diplomatic Options Open Up With Syria and Iran
articles.snippet: President Obama is facing two unexpected diplomatic initiatives with the United States’ biggest adversaries in the Middle East, Syria and Iran, each fraught with opportunity and danger.
articles.abstract: President Obama is facing two unexpected diplomatic initiatives with the United States’ biggest adversaries in the Middle East, Syria and Iran, each fraught with opportunity and danger.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Only two weeks after Washington and the nation were debating a unilateral military strike on Syria that was also intended as a forceful warning to Iran about its nuclear program, President Obama finds himself at the opening stages of two unexpected diplomatic initiatives with America’s biggest adversaries in the Middle East, each fraught with opportunity and danger.

articles.headline: U.S. Revives Aid Program for Clean Energy
articles.snippet: A controversial federal loan-guarantee program intended to support greener energy technologies will shift to supporting development of cleaner oil and coal technology.
articles.abstract: A controversial federal loan-guarantee program intended to support greener energy technologies will shift to supporting development of cleaner oil and coal technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has decided to revive a controversial loan guarantee program at the Energy Department, administration officials said on Thursday, even as the program remains under Congressional scrutiny after losing hundreds of millions in taxpayer money on investments in failed green energy start-ups like the solar module maker Solyndra.

articles.headline: Misgivings About How a Weed Killer Affects the Soil
articles.snippet: Some farmers are examining their soil, and finding cause for concern after years of using glyphosate to kill weeds in their fields.
articles.abstract: Some farmers are examining their soil, and finding cause for concern after years of using glyphosate to kill weeds in their fields.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALTON, Iowa — The puny, yellow corn stalks stand like weary sentries on one boundary of Dennis Von Arb’s field here.

articles.headline: Amid Economic Stress, Differing Strategies Emerge
articles.snippet: Indonesia must get used to higher interest rates, its vice president said Friday, while India’s central bank decided it needed to lower its rates.
articles.abstract: Indonesia must get used to higher interest rates, its vice president said Friday, while India’s central bank decided it needed to lower its rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: JAKARTA — Indonesia and India, the two emerging markets hardest hit in recent weeks by falling currencies and other financial troubles, took opposite tracks on Friday as both countries struggled to balance growth with the threat of inflation.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Joe Cochrane

articles.headline: As It Makes Overtures to Iran, U.S. Strives to Reassure Israel
articles.snippet: As the United States reaches out to Iran’s new president, White House officials are trying to convince skeptical Israelis that they will not prematurely ease pressure on Tehran to curb its nuclear program.
articles.abstract: As the United States reaches out to Iran’s new president, White House officials are trying to convince skeptical Israelis that they will not prematurely ease pressure on Tehran to curb its nuclear program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Obama administration embarks on a highly visible diplomatic overture to Iran, White House officials are engaged in a quieter, behind-the-scenes effort to reassure Israel that they will not fall for the charms of Iran’s new president by prematurely easing pressure on his government to curb its nuclear program.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Jodi Rudoren

articles.headline: House Bill Links Health Care Law and Budget Plan
articles.snippet: Without a resolution, large swaths of the government could shut down Oct. 1, and a first-ever default on federal debt could follow weeks later.
articles.abstract: Without a resolution, large swaths of the government could shut down Oct. 1, and a first-ever default on federal debt could follow weeks later.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans muscled through a stopgap bill Friday that would fund the government only if all spending for President Obama’s health care law is eliminated. Senate Democrats and President Obama quickly made it clear they had no intention of going along, putting the government on a course toward a shutdown unless one side relents.
